Understanding models and data 2024-25

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 7
Credits:15
Module Code:LIFE762
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 
In Programmes:Emerging Infections and Pandemics MSc 2024-25
Advanced Biological Sciences (full-time) MRes 2024-25
Advanced Biological Sciences (part-time) MRes 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Understanding models and data
Short Title
Understanding models and data

LIFE762

2024-25

HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module will train students in the statistical and mathematical literacy required to become confident consumers of data and models, against the backdrop of a large disease outbreak or a pandemic. The material will also complement the other statistical programme modules, which place a more traditional emphasis on the student as a user of statistics, prioritising techniques for data collection and statistical analysis.

The module will
• Discuss the importance of context to all quantitative data;
• Introduce the skills required to understand the distinction between mathematical and statistical models, what each can provide and when it is appropriate to use them
• Discuss the assumptions behind different types of mathematical and computer models, and their strengths and weaknesses
• Demonstrate how to read a paper and critically appraise the quantitative information it presents;
• Discuss how to use simple exploratory statistical approaches, including data visualisation techniques, to gain pertinent insight from epidemiological data.

Consideration will be given to how ill-judged statistical representation can mislead, drawing upon high-profile examples from the media, and provide guidance on how to spot “dubious” statistics.

The module will assume that students are familiar with basic statistical techniques and concepts (e.g. linear regression, p-values) and will require an entry-level competence in using software which can produce a simple visualisation or graphic (for example, Excel, R, Minitab.) Any knowledge gap in incoming students will be assessed at the start of the module using an MCQ, and students will be provided with online resources and a background-appropriate reading list as required. The module will be taught by a combination of lectures, seminars, workshops and self-directed learning, and will be assessed using a presentation and a short report.
Educational Aims
This module will

• Introduce the skills required to understand the distinction between mathematical and statistical models, what each can provide, and when it is appropriate to use them
• Discuss the importance of context in quantitative data, and how to use exploratory statistical approaches to gain pertinent insight from epidemiological data
• Explain the assumptions, strengths, and limitations of different types of mathematical models
• Demonstrate how to understand and deal with different types of uncertainty
• Demonstrate how to read a paper and critically appraise the quantitative information it presents
Marketing Module Synopsis
In recent years, data and statistics have become a feature of emerging public health situations to an extent that is historically unprecedented. Scientists, policy makers and the public have had to become confident consumers of numbers and model predictions. The actors involved in the management of infectious diseases are not necessarily modelling specialists themselves, but nevertheless need to interpret statistical and modelling results and be aware of their limitations.

This module will train students to understand what can and cannot be learnt from data and modelling results. The module does not assume that students are experts in statistics or modelling. Students will receive training in how to use simple visualisations and analysis to gain a robust understanding of key patterns in data, and how to recognise common pitfalls in data interpretation. Students will learn the distinction between different approaches in statistics and quantitative modelling, and when it is appropriate to use them. Particular attention will be paid to the management of uncertainty in model predictions. The module will equip students to interpret critically the quantitative results in scientific papers and reports, and how to use them to inform the management of infectious diseases. The module will be assessed by the combination of a presentation and a short report, in the spirit of authentic assessment.
Outline Syllabus
The module will be organized according to the following topics:

(1) What is a model?

• Key terms and concepts
• Inductive vs. deductive reasoning
• Distinction between mathematical and statistical models
• Where different models are used

(2) Simple statistics
• The importance of context in interpreting data
• The importance of consideration of uncertainty in interpreting patterns
• Simple graphical representations of data
• Summary statistics
• Checking model assumptions

(3) Mathematical models
• Principles of process-based models
• Differential equations
• Models of population dynamics
• Epidemiological models and concepts
• The importance of space and stochasticity
• Agent-based models

(4) Dealing with uncertainty
• Types of uncertainty (measurement, inferential, process, structural)
• Frequentist and Bayesian approaches for quantifying uncertainty
• Simulation based models for exploring scenarios
• Planning for extreme events

Components of the syllabus will comprise: directed reading, asynchronous lectures, seminars, computer-based practical sessions, and workshops in which students are given the opportunity to complete formative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The teaching methods below were designed to align with The Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks and Attributes. We will draw upon key examples from papers in the literature and reports to government that have gone on to inform policy decisions, inspired by the need for research-connected teaching leading to authentic assessment. Active learning opportunities will be a priority, with discussion groups based upon students’ own interpretation of the key research material that has historically informed public health policy, and students being encouraged to find and their own position regarding the status of the evidence base (reflected also in the design of Task 1 for assessment.)

Teaching method 1 – asynchronous lectures
Description: recorded lectures to introduce key subject matter, drawing upon high-profile real-word examples to provide relevant context. Lectures will be organised under the following headings: What is a model? (distinctions between different types of models and contexts for application); Simple statistics (exploratory approaches which can provide helpful context and help the reader understand uncertainty); mathematical models (covering the key classes of models at an appropriate level of detail); and dealing with uncertainty (Bayesian and classical approaches to uncertainty).
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching method 2 – Seminar
Description: interactive sessions to explore material introduced in the asynchronous lectures. These will include questions to test understanding and promote discussion, and may as appropriate include visiting speakers who are specialists on the linked lecture subject matter and will be encouraged to engage the students in discussion: in taking this approach we will promote a research-led focus to the sessions. Topics covered will include simple statistics; modelling in epidemiology; approaches to uncertainty; critical appraisal skills; the use of data in public health research.
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching method 3 – Workshop
Description: Students will be set a task to perform, either individually or in groups. Topics for the sessions will be motivated by the material in the asynchronous lectures and follow-on seminars and will promote the development of a range of skills amongst the students: working as a member of a team; developing self-directed lines of enquiry; understanding quantitative information presented in research papers and applying learning from the lectures and seminars in critically appraising results as presented; scrutinising, understanding and explaining to teachers and their peer group the most recent and topical research; and applying the knowledge gained to hypothetical real-world contexts.
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching Method 4 - Practical
Description: Guided workshops to supplement learning: computer-based practical sessions focusing first on the software to be used (supplemented by online learning materials available to all students), and then exploring a variety of simple statistical approaches, simple differential equation models, agent-based models; and a separate practical session focusing upon a formative task which will guide the students in their approaches required for their assessments.
Attendance Recorded: Y

Unscheduled Directed Student Hours (time spent away from the timetabled sessions but directed by the teaching staff):
Description: Students will be expected to engage with a wide variety of sources: research papers, media articles, data analyses, governmental reports, and scrutinise and criticise the quantitative information (statistical or mathematical) that they present, then apply their learning to real-world contexts up for discussion in workshops and seminars. Guidance will be provided on software for data analysis and modelling in two initial practical sessions, but students will be expected to develop their own learning with the aid of online resources and a reading list which will be made available. Time will be spent preparing for workshops, the material for which will be set in advance, and they may be required to work either independently or in a group in these activities.
Assessment Strategy
Our proposed approaches to assessment (two tasks outlined below) respect the Hallmarks set down in The Liverpool Curriculum Framework*:

The basing of Task 1 which is a presentation on a self-chosen, topical selection of research papers, which summarise the evidence for or against the effectiveness of a student-selected intervention for control of an outbreak-causing disease agent, is very much designed in the spirit of research-connected teaching and is tailored to this module’s content. The same is true of Task 2, which will require the student to explain, in a short report, the technical details of a specialist paper in lay terms, to critically appraise the model and to suggest improvements. Both activities will aid in the building of confident scientists who can think critically about the evidence around them. The second part of Task 1, which involves the description, graphical or otherwise as the student deems most appropriate, of data or modelling output relevant to the task, will involve the student in several areas of self-directed activity which are relevant to digital fluency: software selection; decision on the best way to summarise the information, either descriptively or graphically, including consideration of data formatting and design. Task 1 additionally exemplifies active learning, through its departure from the traditional lecturer-recipient delivery and focus upon student-led article selection and critical appraisal to deliver the assessment outcome.

Finally, both assessments are constructed in the spirit of authentic assessment, presenting the student with tasks which typify the kinds of activities in which they may find themselves involved in professional life following graduation: Task 1 is assessed by presentation accompanied by model and data descriptions using appropriate techniques; Task 2 by a short report which is by design concise. All of these seek to represent skills which students can realistically expect to find themselves using in the workplace, for example, how to represent technical information in a concise manner. Both assessments will encourage our graduates to develop as confident, independent and critical thinkers who possess the technological and digital skills which will help them in their professional life to respond in an appropriate and measured manner to quantitative information.

During the critical appraisal skills part of the module there will be an opportunity to make a presentation to the peer group which will take a similar format to that which takes place in Task 1. We will also give the students the chance to critique a paper which presents a model , much as the requirement for Task 2, and formative feedback will be provided.

Task 1: As a group, decide on a research question related to a disease outbreak or pandemic control intervention (“do lockdowns/facemasks/vaccines work?”.) The group will divide among themselves the task of researching the relevant literature. The group will then make a joint presentation. Each group member will summarise the evidence they have gathered concerning the intervention for pandemic mitigation. Finally, the group will present their consensus conclusions to the instructors and other students. Peer moderation will be used to reflect on the activity of group learning.

Task 2: Describe in concise and non-specialist language the modelling approach (and its assumptions and limitations) used in a paper. Critically appraise the work and suggest areas for improvement.

Reassessment
Task 1. Reassessment is available. The student will be required to select a different intervention-associated question from that selected at their first group-based attempt for investigation. They will locate research papers from the relevant literature, summarise the evidence they have gathered concerning the intervention for pandemic mitigation, and then present their conclusions around the impact of the intervention for pandemic mitigation to the instructors/other students. Mark will be capped at 50%. It will take place in the normal reassessment period.

Task 2. Reassessment is available. Students will be required to summarise a different paper from that upon which their first attempt was based: they will then describe in concise and non-specialist language the modelling approach (and its assumptions and limitations) used in the paper, and critically appraise the work and suggest areas for improvement. Mark will be capped at 50%. It will take place in the normal reassessment period.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

*https://www.liverpool.ac.uk/centre-for-innovation-in-education/curriculum-resources/

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Critically appraise, evaluate and interpret knowledge of a wide range of topics in mathematical and statistical modelling, and apply your understanding of mathematical and statistical models to discuss their use in the context of a pandemic or a large infectious disease outbreak.
 M2 Justify and explain the importance of context in representation of numerical or statistical data in the course of a pandemic or disease outbreak, and demonstrate clear ability to provide critical evaluation of biases and limitations to inference when proper context is not provided.
 M3 Critically appraise the presentation of statistical data and interpretation of analysis, and suggest areas for improvement with reference to specific case studies from the literature.
 M4 Evaluate and compare a range of approaches for describing uncertainty in data and models, e.g. Bayesian statistics and confidence intervals, and explain the different sources of uncertainty in mathematical and statistical modelling.
 M5 Critically appraise and explain to a non-specialist quantitative information as presented in an academic research paper, a report to government, or a media news article.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Numeracy (understanding of quantitative information); the ability to distinguish between mathematical and statistical models; understanding of basic measures of uncertainty
 S2 Critical appraisal: the ability to interrogate and criticise the research and reporting of others, and identify common errors and areas of weakness
 S3 Presentation skills and confidence in communicating statistical and numerate concepts to non-specialists.
 S4 Group working (delegate and divide tasks; communication skills; reaching consensus)

Understanding models and data 2024-25

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 7
Credits:15
Module Code:LIFE762
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 
In Programmes:Emerging Infections and Pandemics MSc 2024-25
Advanced Biological Sciences (full-time) MRes 2024-25
Advanced Biological Sciences (part-time) MRes 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Understanding models and data
Short Title
Understanding models and data

LIFE762
Academic Year
2024-25

HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module will train students in the statistical and mathematical literacy required to become confident consumers of data and models, against the backdrop of a large disease outbreak or a pandemic. The material will also complement the other statistical programme modules, which place a more traditional emphasis on the student as a user of statistics, prioritising techniques for data collection and statistical analysis.

The module will
• Discuss the importance of context to all quantitative data;
• Introduce the skills required to understand the distinction between mathematical and statistical models, what each can provide and when it is appropriate to use them
• Discuss the assumptions behind different types of mathematical and computer models, and their strengths and weaknesses
• Demonstrate how to read a paper and critically appraise the quantitative information it presents;
• Discuss how to use simple exploratory statistical approaches, including data visualisation techniques, to gain pertinent insight from epidemiological data.

Consideration will be given to how ill-judged statistical representation can mislead, drawing upon high-profile examples from the media, and provide guidance on how to spot “dubious” statistics.

The module will assume that students are familiar with basic statistical techniques and concepts (e.g. linear regression, p-values) and will require an entry-level competence in using software which can produce a simple visualisation or graphic (for example, Excel, R, Minitab.) Any knowledge gap in incoming students will be assessed at the start of the module using an MCQ, and students will be provided with online resources and a background-appropriate reading list as required. The module will be taught by a combination of lectures, seminars, workshops and self-directed learning, and will be assessed using a presentation and a short report.
Educational Aims
This module will

• Introduce the skills required to understand the distinction between mathematical and statistical models, what each can provide, and when it is appropriate to use them
• Discuss the importance of context in quantitative data, and how to use exploratory statistical approaches to gain pertinent insight from epidemiological data
• Explain the assumptions, strengths, and limitations of different types of mathematical models
• Demonstrate how to understand and deal with different types of uncertainty
• Demonstrate how to read a paper and critically appraise the quantitative information it presents
Marketing Module Synopsis
In recent years, data and statistics have become a feature of emerging public health situations to an extent that is historically unprecedented. Scientists, policy makers and the public have had to become confident consumers of numbers and model predictions. The actors involved in the management of infectious diseases are not necessarily modelling specialists themselves, but nevertheless need to interpret statistical and modelling results and be aware of their limitations.

This module will train students to understand what can and cannot be learnt from data and modelling results. The module does not assume that students are experts in statistics or modelling. Students will receive training in how to use simple visualisations and analysis to gain a robust understanding of key patterns in data, and how to recognise common pitfalls in data interpretation. Students will learn the distinction between different approaches in statistics and quantitative modelling, and when it is appropriate to use them. Particular attention will be paid to the management of uncertainty in model predictions. The module will equip students to interpret critically the quantitative results in scientific papers and reports, and how to use them to inform the management of infectious diseases. The module will be assessed by the combination of a presentation and a short report, in the spirit of authentic assessment.
Outline Syllabus
The module will be organized according to the following topics:

(1) What is a model?

• Key terms and concepts
• Inductive vs. deductive reasoning
• Distinction between mathematical and statistical models
• Where different models are used

(2) Simple statistics
• The importance of context in interpreting data
• The importance of consideration of uncertainty in interpreting patterns
• Simple graphical representations of data
• Summary statistics
• Checking model assumptions

(3) Mathematical models
• Principles of process-based models
• Differential equations
• Models of population dynamics
• Epidemiological models and concepts
• The importance of space and stochasticity
• Agent-based models

(4) Dealing with uncertainty
• Types of uncertainty (measurement, inferential, process, structural)
• Frequentist and Bayesian approaches for quantifying uncertainty
• Simulation based models for exploring scenarios
• Planning for extreme events

Components of the syllabus will comprise: directed reading, asynchronous lectures, seminars, computer-based practical sessions, and workshops in which students are given the opportunity to complete formative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The teaching methods below were designed to align with The Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks and Attributes. We will draw upon key examples from papers in the literature and reports to government that have gone on to inform policy decisions, inspired by the need for research-connected teaching leading to authentic assessment. Active learning opportunities will be a priority, with discussion groups based upon students’ own interpretation of the key research material that has historically informed public health policy, and students being encouraged to find and their own position regarding the status of the evidence base (reflected also in the design of Task 1 for assessment.)

Teaching method 1 – asynchronous lectures
Description: recorded lectures to introduce key subject matter, drawing upon high-profile real-word examples to provide relevant context. Lectures will be organised under the following headings: What is a model? (distinctions between different types of models and contexts for application); Simple statistics (exploratory approaches which can provide helpful context and help the reader understand uncertainty); mathematical models (covering the key classes of models at an appropriate level of detail); and dealing with uncertainty (Bayesian and classical approaches to uncertainty).
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching method 2 – Seminar
Description: interactive sessions to explore material introduced in the asynchronous lectures. These will include questions to test understanding and promote discussion, and may as appropriate include visiting speakers who are specialists on the linked lecture subject matter and will be encouraged to engage the students in discussion: in taking this approach we will promote a research-led focus to the sessions. Topics covered will include simple statistics; modelling in epidemiology; approaches to uncertainty; critical appraisal skills; the use of data in public health research.
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching method 3 – Workshop
Description: Students will be set a task to perform, either individually or in groups. Topics for the sessions will be motivated by the material in the asynchronous lectures and follow-on seminars and will promote the development of a range of skills amongst the students: working as a member of a team; developing self-directed lines of enquiry; understanding quantitative information presented in research papers and applying learning from the lectures and seminars in critically appraising results as presented; scrutinising, understanding and explaining to teachers and their peer group the most recent and topical research; and applying the knowledge gained to hypothetical real-world contexts.
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching Method 4 - Practical
Description: Guided workshops to supplement learning: computer-based practical sessions focusing first on the software to be used (supplemented by online learning materials available to all students), and then exploring a variety of simple statistical approaches, simple differential equation models, agent-based models; and a separate practical session focusing upon a formative task which will guide the students in their approaches required for their assessments.
Attendance Recorded: Y

Unscheduled Directed Student Hours (time spent away from the timetabled sessions but directed by the teaching staff):
Description: Students will be expected to engage with a wide variety of sources: research papers, media articles, data analyses, governmental reports, and scrutinise and criticise the quantitative information (statistical or mathematical) that they present, then apply their learning to real-world contexts up for discussion in workshops and seminars. Guidance will be provided on software for data analysis and modelling in two initial practical sessions, but students will be expected to develop their own learning with the aid of online resources and a reading list which will be made available. Time will be spent preparing for workshops, the material for which will be set in advance, and they may be required to work either independently or in a group in these activities.
Assessment Strategy
Our proposed approaches to assessment (two tasks outlined below) respect the Hallmarks set down in The Liverpool Curriculum Framework*:

The basing of Task 1 which is a presentation on a self-chosen, topical selection of research papers, which summarise the evidence for or against the effectiveness of a student-selected intervention for control of an outbreak-causing disease agent, is very much designed in the spirit of research-connected teaching and is tailored to this module’s content. The same is true of Task 2, which will require the student to explain, in a short report, the technical details of a specialist paper in lay terms, to critically appraise the model and to suggest improvements. Both activities will aid in the building of confident scientists who can think critically about the evidence around them. The second part of Task 1, which involves the description, graphical or otherwise as the student deems most appropriate, of data or modelling output relevant to the task, will involve the student in several areas of self-directed activity which are relevant to digital fluency: software selection; decision on the best way to summarise the information, either descriptively or graphically, including consideration of data formatting and design. Task 1 additionally exemplifies active learning, through its departure from the traditional lecturer-recipient delivery and focus upon student-led article selection and critical appraisal to deliver the assessment outcome.

Finally, both assessments are constructed in the spirit of authentic assessment, presenting the student with tasks which typify the kinds of activities in which they may find themselves involved in professional life following graduation: Task 1 is assessed by presentation accompanied by model and data descriptions using appropriate techniques; Task 2 by a short report which is by design concise. All of these seek to represent skills which students can realistically expect to find themselves using in the workplace, for example, how to represent technical information in a concise manner. Both assessments will encourage our graduates to develop as confident, independent and critical thinkers who possess the technological and digital skills which will help them in their professional life to respond in an appropriate and measured manner to quantitative information.

During the critical appraisal skills part of the module there will be an opportunity to make a presentation to the peer group which will take a similar format to that which takes place in Task 1. We will also give the students the chance to critique a paper which presents a model , much as the requirement for Task 2, and formative feedback will be provided.

Task 1: As a group, decide on a research question related to a disease outbreak or pandemic control intervention (“do lockdowns/facemasks/vaccines work?”.) The group will divide among themselves the task of researching the relevant literature. The group will then make a joint presentation. Each group member will summarise the evidence they have gathered concerning the intervention for pandemic mitigation. Finally, the group will present their consensus conclusions to the instructors and other students. Peer moderation will be used to reflect on the activity of group learning.

Task 2: Describe in concise and non-specialist language the modelling approach (and its assumptions and limitations) used in a paper. Critically appraise the work and suggest areas for improvement.

Reassessment
Task 1. Reassessment is available. The student will be required to select a different intervention-associated question from that selected at their first group-based attempt for investigation. They will locate research papers from the relevant literature, summarise the evidence they have gathered concerning the intervention for pandemic mitigation, and then present their conclusions around the impact of the intervention for pandemic mitigation to the instructors/other students. Mark will be capped at 50%. It will take place in the normal reassessment period.

Task 2. Reassessment is available. Students will be required to summarise a different paper from that upon which their first attempt was based: they will then describe in concise and non-specialist language the modelling approach (and its assumptions and limitations) used in the paper, and critically appraise the work and suggest areas for improvement. Mark will be capped at 50%. It will take place in the normal reassessment period.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

*https://www.liverpool.ac.uk/centre-for-innovation-in-education/curriculum-resources/

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Critically appraise, evaluate and interpret knowledge of a wide range of topics in mathematical and statistical modelling, and apply your understanding of mathematical and statistical models to discuss their use in the context of a pandemic or a large infectious disease outbreak.
 M2 Justify and explain the importance of context in representation of numerical or statistical data in the course of a pandemic or disease outbreak, and demonstrate clear ability to provide critical evaluation of biases and limitations to inference when proper context is not provided.
 M3 Critically appraise the presentation of statistical data and interpretation of analysis, and suggest areas for improvement with reference to specific case studies from the literature.
 M4 Evaluate and compare a range of approaches for describing uncertainty in data and models, e.g. Bayesian statistics and confidence intervals, and explain the different sources of uncertainty in mathematical and statistical modelling.
 M5 Critically appraise and explain to a non-specialist quantitative information as presented in an academic research paper, a report to government, or a media news article.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Numeracy (understanding of quantitative information); the ability to distinguish between mathematical and statistical models; understanding of basic measures of uncertainty
 S2 Critical appraisal: the ability to interrogate and criticise the research and reporting of others, and identify common errors and areas of weakness
 S3 Presentation skills and confidence in communicating statistical and numerate concepts to non-specialists.
 S4 Group working (delegate and divide tasks; communication skills; reaching consensus)

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Critically appraise, evaluate and interpret knowledge of a wide range of topics in mathematical and statistical modelling, and apply your understanding of mathematical and statistical models to discuss their use in the context of a pandemic or a large infectious disease outbreak.

 M3 Critically appraise the presentation of statistical data and interpretation of analysis, and suggest areas for improvement with reference to specific case studies from the literature.
 M4 Evaluate and compare a range of approaches for describing uncertainty in data and models, e.g. Bayesian statistics and confidence intervals, and explain the different sources of uncertainty in mathematical and statistical modelling.
 M5 Critically appraise and explain to a non-specialist quantitative information as presented in an academic research paper, a report to government, or a media news article.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Numeracy (understanding of quantitative information); the ability to distinguish between mathematical and statistical models; understanding of basic measures of uncertainty
 S2 Critical appraisal: the ability to interrogate and criticise the research and reporting of others, and identify common errors and areas of weakness
 S3 Presentation skills and confidence in communicating statistical and numerate concepts to non-specialists.
 S4 Group working (delegate and divide tasks; communication skills; reaching consensus)

Blurb
Overview
This module will train students in the statistical and mathematical literacy required to become confident consumers of data and models, against the backdrop of a large disease outbreak or a pandemic. The material will also complement the other statistical programme modules, which place a more traditional emphasis on the student as a user of statistics, prioritising techniques for data collection and statistical analysis.

The module will
• Discuss the importance of context to all quantitative data;
• Introduce the skills required to understand the distinction between mathematical and statistical models, what each can provide and when it is appropriate to use them
• Discuss the assumptions behind different types of mathematical and computer models, and their strengths and weaknesses
• Demonstrate how to read a paper and critically appraise the quantitative information it presents;
• Discuss how to use simple exploratory statistical approaches, including data visualisation techniques, to gain pertinent insight from epidemiological data.

Consideration will be given to how ill-judged statistical representation can mislead, drawing upon high-profile examples from the media, and provide guidance on how to spot “dubious” statistics.

The module will assume that students are familiar with basic statistical techniques and concepts (e.g. linear regression, p-values) and will require an entry-level competence in using software which can produce a simple visualisation or graphic (for example, Excel, R, Minitab.) Any knowledge gap in incoming students will be assessed at the start of the module using an MCQ, and students will be provided with online resources and a background-appropriate reading list as required. The module will be taught by a combination of lectures, seminars, workshops and self-directed learning, and will be assessed using a presentation and a short report.
Educational Aims
This module will

• Introduce the skills required to understand the distinction between mathematical and statistical models, what each can provide, and when it is appropriate to use them
• Discuss the importance of context in quantitative data, and how to use exploratory statistical approaches to gain pertinent insight from epidemiological data
• Explain the assumptions, strengths, and limitations of different types of mathematical models
• Demonstrate how to understand and deal with different types of uncertainty
• Demonstrate how to read a paper and critically appraise the quantitative information it presents
Marketing Module Synopsis
In recent years, data and statistics have become a feature of emerging public health situations to an extent that is historically unprecedented. Scientists, policy makers and the public have had to become confident consumers of numbers and model predictions. The actors involved in the management of infectious diseases are not necessarily modelling specialists themselves, but nevertheless need to interpret statistical and modelling results and be aware of their limitations.

This module will train students to understand what can and cannot be learnt from data and modelling results. The module does not assume that students are experts in statistics or modelling. Students will receive training in how to use simple visualisations and analysis to gain a robust understanding of key patterns in data, and how to recognise common pitfalls in data interpretation. Students will learn the distinction between different approaches in statistics and quantitative modelling, and when it is appropriate to use them. Particular attention will be paid to the management of uncertainty in model predictions. The module will equip students to interpret critically the quantitative results in scientific papers and reports, and how to use them to inform the management of infectious diseases. The module will be assessed by the combination of a presentation and a short report, in the spirit of authentic assessment.
Outline Syllabus
The module will be organized according to the following topics:

(1) What is a model?

• Key terms and concepts
• Inductive vs. deductive reasoning
• Distinction between mathematical and statistical models
• Where different models are used

(2) Simple statistics
• The importance of context in interpreting data
• The importance of consideration of uncertainty in interpreting patterns
• Simple graphical representations of data
• Summary statistics
• Checking model assumptions

(3) Mathematical models
• Principles of process-based models
• Differential equations
• Models of population dynamics
• Epidemiological models and concepts
• The importance of space and stochasticity
• Agent-based models

(4) Dealing with uncertainty
• Types of uncertainty (measurement, inferential, process, structural)
• Frequentist and Bayesian approaches for quantifying uncertainty
• Simulation based models for exploring scenarios
• Planning for extreme events

Components of the syllabus will comprise: directed reading, asynchronous lectures, seminars, computer-based practical sessions, and workshops in which students are given the opportunity to complete formative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The teaching methods below were designed to align with The Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks and Attributes. We will draw upon key examples from papers in the literature and reports to government that have gone on to inform policy decisions, inspired by the need for research-connected teaching leading to authentic assessment. Active learning opportunities will be a priority, with discussion groups based upon students’ own interpretation of the key research material that has historically informed public health policy, and students being encouraged to find and their own position regarding the status of the evidence base (reflected also in the design of Task 1 for assessment.)

Teaching method 1 – asynchronous lectures
Description: recorded lectures to introduce key subject matter, drawing upon high-profile real-word examples to provide relevant context. Lectures will be organised under the following headings: What is a model? (distinctions between different types of models and contexts for application); Simple statistics (exploratory approaches which can provide helpful context and help the reader understand uncertainty); mathematical models (covering the key classes of models at an appropriate level of detail); and dealing with uncertainty (Bayesian and classical approaches to uncertainty).
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching method 2 – Seminar
Description: interactive sessions to explore material introduced in the asynchronous lectures. These will include questions to test understanding and promote discussion, and may as appropriate include visiting speakers who are specialists on the linked lecture subject matter and will be encouraged to engage the students in discussion: in taking this approach we will promote a research-led focus to the sessions. Topics covered will include simple statistics; modelling in epidemiology; approaches to uncertainty; critical appraisal skills; the use of data in public health research.
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching method 3 – Workshop
Description: Students will be set a task to perform, either individually or in groups. Topics for the sessions will be motivated by the material in the asynchronous lectures and follow-on seminars and will promote the development of a range of skills amongst the students: working as a member of a team; developing self-directed lines of enquiry; understanding quantitative information presented in research papers and applying learning from the lectures and seminars in critically appraising results as presented; scrutinising, understanding and explaining to teachers and their peer group the most recent and topical research; and applying the knowledge gained to hypothetical real-world contexts.
Attendance recorded: Y

Teaching Method 4 - Practical
Description: Guided workshops to supplement learning: computer-based practical sessions focusing first on the software to be used (supplemented by online learning materials available to all students), and then exploring a variety of simple statistical approaches, simple differential equation models, agent-based models; and a separate practical session focusing upon a formative task which will guide the students in their approaches required for their assessments.
Attendance Recorded: Y

Unscheduled Directed Student Hours (time spent away from the timetabled sessions but directed by the teaching staff):
Description: Students will be expected to engage with a wide variety of sources: research papers, media articles, data analyses, governmental reports, and scrutinise and criticise the quantitative information (statistical or mathematical) that they present, then apply their learning to real-world contexts up for discussion in workshops and seminars. Guidance will be provided on software for data analysis and modelling in two initial practical sessions, but students will be expected to develop their own learning with the aid of online resources and a reading list which will be made available. Time will be spent preparing for workshops, the material for which will be set in advance, and they may be required to work either independently or in a group in these activities.
Assessment Strategy
Our proposed approaches to assessment (two tasks outlined below) respect the Hallmarks set down in The Liverpool Curriculum Framework*:

The basing of Task 1 which is a presentation on a self-chosen, topical selection of research papers, which summarise the evidence for or against the effectiveness of a student-selected intervention for control of an outbreak-causing disease agent, is very much designed in the spirit of research-connected teaching and is tailored to this module’s content. The same is true of Task 2, which will require the student to explain, in a short report, the technical details of a specialist paper in lay terms, to critically appraise the model and to suggest improvements. Both activities will aid in the building of confident scientists who can think critically about the evidence around them. The second part of Task 1, which involves the description, graphical or otherwise as the student deems most appropriate, of data or modelling output relevant to the task, will involve the student in several areas of self-directed activity which are relevant to digital fluency: software selection; decision on the best way to summarise the information, either descriptively or graphically, including consideration of data formatting and design. Task 1 additionally exemplifies active learning, through its departure from the traditional lecturer-recipient delivery and focus upon student-led article selection and critical appraisal to deliver the assessment outcome.

Finally, both assessments are constructed in the spirit of authentic assessment, presenting the student with tasks which typify the kinds of activities in which they may find themselves involved in professional life following graduation: Task 1 is assessed by presentation accompanied by model and data descriptions using appropriate techniques; Task 2 by a short report which is by design concise. All of these seek to represent skills which students can realistically expect to find themselves using in the workplace, for example, how to represent technical information in a concise manner. Both assessments will encourage our graduates to develop as confident, independent and critical thinkers who possess the technological and digital skills which will help them in their professional life to respond in an appropriate and measured manner to quantitative information.

During the critical appraisal skills part of the module there will be an opportunity to make a presentation to the peer group which will take a similar format to that which takes place in Task 1. We will also give the students the chance to critique a paper which presents a model , much as the requirement for Task 2, and formative feedback will be provided.

Task 1: As a group, decide on a research question related to a disease outbreak or pandemic control intervention (“do lockdowns/facemasks/vaccines work?”.) The group will divide among themselves the task of researching the relevant literature. The group will then make a joint presentation. Each group member will summarise the evidence they have gathered concerning the intervention for pandemic mitigation. Finally, the group will present their consensus conclusions to the instructors and other students. Peer moderation will be used to reflect on the activity of group learning.

Task 2: Describe in concise and non-specialist language the modelling approach (and its assumptions and limitations) used in a paper. Critically appraise the work and suggest areas for improvement.

Reassessment
Task 1. Reassessment is available. The student will be required to select a different intervention-associated question from that selected at their first group-based attempt for investigation. They will locate research papers from the relevant literature, summarise the evidence they have gathered concerning the intervention for pandemic mitigation, and then present their conclusions around the impact of the intervention for pandemic mitigation to the instructors/other students. Mark will be capped at 50%. It will take place in the normal reassessment period.

Task 2. Reassessment is available. Students will be required to summarise a different paper from that upon which their first attempt was based: they will then describe in concise and non-specialist language the modelling approach (and its assumptions and limitations) used in the paper, and critically appraise the work and suggest areas for improvement. Mark will be capped at 50%. It will take place in the normal reassessment period.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

*https://www.liverpool.ac.uk/centre-for-innovation-in-education/curriculum-resources/

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M1 Critically appraise, evaluate and interpret knowledge of a wide range of topics in mathematical and statistical modelling, and apply your understanding of mathematical and statistical models to discuss their use in the context of a pandemic or a large infectious disease outbreak.
 M2 Justify and explain the importance of context in representation of numerical or statistical data in the course of a pandemic or disease outbreak, and demonstrate clear ability to provide critical evaluation of biases and limitations to inference when proper context is not provided.
 M3 Critically appraise the presentation of statistical data and interpretation of analysis, and suggest areas for improvement with reference to specific case studies from the literature.
 M4 Evaluate and compare a range of approaches for describing uncertainty in data and models, e.g. Bayesian statistics and confidence intervals, and explain the different sources of uncertainty in mathematical and statistical modelling.
 M5 Critically appraise and explain to a non-specialist quantitative information as presented in an academic research paper, a report to government, or a media news article.
